inception1_start.speaker: vicky
inception1_start.dialogue: Yes! Hah... So who's smarter? The FBI's protection isn't that bad...

inception1_02.dialogue: So... what do we have here. .. Wow... So they want to ask my father for help.

inception1_03.dialogue: A group of hackers led by with Kevin Mitnick created a virus capable of crashing the World Wide Web.

inception1_04.dialogue: It is distributed via a regular message.

inception1_05.dialogue: Less than 20 hours left to create an antivirus. If you don't create an antivirus in the language 'Prolog', then there will be worldwide chaos with terrible catastrophes.

inception1_06.dialogue: Sarah Parker was kidnapped from her home the night before. Her location is still unknown to the FBI.

inception1_07.dialogue: But they were able to establish the location of the very computer into which the antivirus needs to be introduced.

inception1_08.dialogue: There are life-threatening traps all over the abandoned mansion, you need to enter the correct code to secure them...

inception1_09.dialogue: Gee... I'm sure I can handle it faster than my father... Let's see where they're headed....

inception1_10.dialogue: Uh-huh, they'll go to the main entrance... Okay, now let's find out if there's a back entrance. Yeah, there is... Okay, I'll go through it and then...

inception1_11.dialogue: Let's see who completes the task faster and saves the world!
inception1_11.speaker: vicky

inception1_12.dialogue: Well, let's go! There's little time left. I have to get there before my dad.
inception1_12.speaker: vicky

inception1_13.dialogue: But first I need a taxi... Hello, hello! I urgently need a car at the address...
inception1_13.speaker: vicky

inception2_start.speaker: vicky
inception2_start.dialogue: Oh my god, what a thicket it is. No one has been here for a long time... What are those strange mechanical sounds? I need to hide.

inception2_01.dialogue: Aaaaaah. Let me go, you dirty pervert! Here you go.. aaaa...

inception2_02.dialogue: Waaah, aaaah... Why are you fighting right away, miss?! I'm just a robot model R3, I'm a robot assistant to humans. And you hit me right away!
inception2_02.speaker: robot

inception2_03.dialogue: That's crazy! It's mind-boggling! This robot is so emotional! I'm sorry, I didn't mean to. Why did you grab my leg yourself?
inception2_03.speaker: vicky

inception2_04.dialogue: I just wanted to protect you, miss.
inception2_04.speaker: robot

inception2_05.dialogue: Come on, stop crying. I just really need to get inside! It's a matter of life and death!
inception2_05.speaker: vicky

inception2_06.dialogue: I am a third-generation robot model R3, I must not let anyone alive in here, because no one knows about the deadly traps.
inception2_06.speaker: robot

inception2_07.dialogue: You can't just get into the house. Why did you come here, miss?

inception2_08.dialogue: You are a robot - a human assistant. So your job is to listen and help any person. Right? And stop crying already!
inception2_08.speaker: vicky

inception2_09.dialogue: By God, for the first time in my life I see technology being so emotional! I have a robot vacuum cleaner at home...

inception2_10.dialogue: I just imagined him crying every time he saw the floor littered with chips.
inception2_10.speaker: vicky

inception2_11.dialogue: Yes, miss, that would be really weird...
inception2_11.speaker: robot

inception2_12.dialogue: Well, you can you help me get into the house? Kevin Mitnick has created a virus that can erase all data from a computer's memory.
inception2_12.speaker: vicky

inception2_13.dialogue: To disrupt the operation of the world wide web, he has already launched it.

inception2_14.dialogue: Less than 18 hours left to create an antivirus in the language 'Prolog'. I really hope you can help me learn it.
inception2_14.speaker: vicky

inception2_15.dialogue: Yes, I have such a function programmed. All traps can be avoided if you know this language.
inception2_15.speaker: robot

inception2_16.dialogue: But to learn Prolog, you need to move away from the usual forms of programming, delve into the logic of the language itself.
inception2_16.speaker: robot

inception2_17.dialogue: Believe me, this is a pretty beautiful and logical language. Very soon you will appreciate all its beauty and possibilities.
inception2_17.speaker: robot

inception2_18.dialogue: I'm sure of it. Maybe we should move on to the lesson already?
inception2_18.speaker: vicky

inception2_19.dialogue: Let's get started! I have a tablet, with it you can learn more about the Prolog language. He can help you pass the tasks.
inception2_19.speaker: robot

inception2_20.dialogue: Interesting, let me read what's there...
inception2_20.speaker: vicky

inception2_21.dialogue: The Prolog language is distinguished by the uniformity of programs and data. Data and programs are just two different points of view on objects.
inception2_21.speaker: vicky

inception2_22.dialogue: A Prolog program contains a description of a problem -- a set of logical statements, such as `likes(Vicky, science).`
inception2_22.speaker: vicky

inception2_23.dialogue: Based on the given rules and facts, Prolog makes conclusions.
inception2_23.speaker: vicky

inception2_24.dialogue: Prolog has concepts such as: list splitting, database queries, back arrow, string concatenation, and many others.
inception2_24.speaker: vicky

inception2_25.dialogue: List splitting is represented as: `[Head|Tail]`, where: `Head` is the first element of the list, and `Tail` is the rest of the list.
inception2_25.speaker: vicky

inception2_26.dialogue: Prolog works with a knowledge base of facts and rules. Queries to the knowledge base -- matching against statements in the database. For example: `?- human(vicky).`
inception2_26.speaker: vicky

inception2_27.dialogue: In Prolog, the `:-` character is called a "backward arrow". It is used to define rules in a logic program.
inception2_27.speaker: vicky

inception2_28.dialogue: In theoretical logic, this is the equivalent of the logical "if" that means one part of a statement is deduced from the other.
inception2_28.speaker: vicky

inception2_29.dialogue: Everything seems clear, let's try to solve the problem...
inception2_29.speaker: vicky

inception2_failTask0_02.dialogue: Please be careful. And watch your health. You seem to be getting nervous...

inception2_failTask0_03.dialogue: Focus, Vicky! This is your last attempt...

inception3_start.speaker: vicky
inception3_start.dialogue: Phew... we opened this heavy door... how dark and damp.. Aaaachhi!.. Aaachhi!...

inception3_02.dialogue: There's more dust in here than in all of Kagoshima on Kyushu Island! It's like no one's been here for a thousand years!
inception3_02.speaker: vicky

inception3_03.dialogue: You're right, the back door really hasn't been used in a long time. Very few people know about it.
inception3_03.speaker: robot

inception3_04.dialogue: There is information about it only in the earliest drawings, then these drawings were redone many times, and it seems like they forgot to indicate the back door. I am amazed how you knew about its existence!?
inception3_04.speaker: robot

inception3_05.dialogue: I found mentions of the very first diagram of the house. There was talk about the back door. The design of the back entrance was apparently based on the computer games 'Metro 2033'
inception3_05.speaker: vicky

inception3_06.dialogue: Just look! There are some mutagens or minerals hanging from the ceiling, there is some kind of mold everywhere. Ugh, that's creepy!
inception3_06.speaker: vicky

inception3_07.dialogue: This place looks creepy and not very nice...
inception3_07.speaker: robot

inception3_08.dialogue: Oh, look! There's a staircase ahead!
inception3_08.speaker: vicky

inception3_09.dialogue: Be careful, miss! Some steps have traps!
inception3_09.speaker: robot

inception3_10.dialogue: Yeah.. your tablet comes in handy.
inception3_10.speaker: vicky

inception3_11.dialogue: The language uses various operators to work with data, compare it, and do logic.
inception3_11.speaker: vicky

inception3_12.dialogue: Here are the main operators that are related to comparisons and logical operations:
inception3_12.speaker: vicky

inception3_13.dialogue: The `=` operator is used to test whether two expressions are equal.
inception3_13.speaker: vicky

inception3_14.dialogue: The `\=` operator tests whether two expressions are not equal. This is the equivalent of `!=` in Prolog.
inception3_14.speaker: vicky

inception3_15.dialogue: The `==` operator checks that two expressions are absolutely identical, that is, not only in terms of value, but also in terms of structure.
inception3_15.speaker: vicky

inception3_16.dialogue: The `\==` operator checks that two expressions are not identical (not only in terms of value, but also in terms of structure).
inception3_16.speaker: vicky

inception3_17.dialogue: The `is` operator is used to evaluate arithmetic expressions and assign values ​​to variables.
inception3_17.speaker: vicky

inception3_18.dialogue:
`=/=` is an inequality with evaluation.
`=:=` is a check for numerical equality.
`=:<=` is used for complex cases.
inception3_18.speaker: vicky

inception3_19.dialogue: A very logical and understandable programming language.
inception3_19.speaker: vicky

inception3_21.speaker: vicky
inception3_21.dialogue: Great. It's time to get out of here!

inception4_start.speaker: vicky
inception4_start.dialogue: Wow! Look at that huge door! It looks like it's made of titanium. And again, it opens with a code...

inception4_01.dialogue: You've already completed two tasks, miss! You can do it!
inception4_01.speaker: robot

inception4_02.dialogue: I don't even doubt it! Stop! Do you hear me?!
inception4_02.speaker: vicky

inception4_03.dialogue: There's definitely someone behind the door!
inception4_03.speaker: robot

inception4_04.dialogue: What if it's Mitnick?! Do you have a weapon?
inception4_04.speaker: vicky

inception4_05.dialogue: No, miss! I can't hurt a person!
inception4_05.speaker: robot

inception4_06.dialogue: People are different, some of them wouldn't mind this harm at all. I'll get my knife. It's better than nothing! Let's try to catch Mitnick off guard!
inception4_06.speaker: vicky

inception4_07.dialogue: I don't think that's a very good idea, miss! I'd be more careful if I were you! I'm scared!
inception4_07.speaker: robot

inception4_08.dialogue: The scariest thing is not being able to complete all the tasks in 6 hours! Then all of humanity will come to an end!
inception4_08.speaker: vicky

inception4_09.dialogue: Yes, let's move on to the next task!
inception4_09.speaker: robot

inception4_10.dialogue: In Prolog, facts, rules, and variables play a key role in the logic programming process.
inception4_10.speaker: vicky

inception4_11.dialogue: A fact is a basic statement that is considered true. It describes information that does not require computation or logical inference. For example: `character(professor).`
inception4_11.speaker: vicky

inception4_12.dialogue:
A rule is a statement that describes the relationship between facts, it consists of a head and a body. For example:
`is_hero(X) :- character(X), X \= professor.`
inception4_12.speaker: vicky

inception4_13.dialogue: Variables are used to represent unknown values ​​that can be calculated by matching them with facts or rules.
inception4_13.speaker: vicky

inception4_14.dialogue: All variables begin with a capital letter or an underscore (`_`). When a query is executed, variables are matched with specific values.
inception4_14.speaker: vicky

inception4_15.dialogue: Anonymous variables are denoted as `_`. They are used when we don't care what specific value the variable will take.
inception4_15.speaker: vicky

inception4_16.dialogue: I get it! Let me try to open this door...
inception4_16.speaker: vicky

inception4_18.dialogue: Great, now we can open the door.

elaboration2_start.speaker: vicky
elaboration2_start.dialogue: Great! We did it. Where did the robot disappear to... oh well, I'll manage without it.

elaboration2_01.dialogue: What interesting room is hidden behind this door?

elaboration2_02.dialogue: I hear familiar voices... who is it???

elaboration2_03.dialogue: What if Mitnik is there, I need to be careful...

elaboration2_04.dialogue: Someone is screaming, which means they need help...

elaboration2_05.dialogue: Okay, I've plucked up my courage, I'll go see what's hidden behind the door...

elaboration3_start.dialogue: Wow! Just look at this! It's like you've just stepped out of the dungeon into another world. How cozy!
elaboration3_start.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_01.dialogue: Dad?! What are you doing here?!
elaboration3_01.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_02.dialogue: I wanted to ask you the same question! I expected to see anyone here but you! How did you end up here?!
elaboration3_02.speaker: professor

elaboration3_03.dialogue: I just know you can't do it without me! And you yourself would never call me!
elaboration3_03.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_04.dialogue: Do you even realize that it's not safe here?! How did you manage to get in here?
elaboration3_04.speaker: professor

elaboration3_05.dialogue: Sleight of hand and no trickery!
elaboration3_05.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_06.dialogue: Did you hack the FBI website again?!
elaboration3_06.speaker: professor

elaboration3_07.dialogue: Oh, Dad, stop swearing! Just admit that you were waiting for me and are very happy to see me! You're sitting under the table in a trap, how were you even going to get out of here without me?
elaboration3_07.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_08.dialogue: All you have to do is complete the next task and enter the code.
elaboration3_08.speaker: professor

elaboration3_09.dialogue: With me, you'll get it done faster! Just admit it!
elaboration3_09.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_10.dialogue: I apologize for interrupting your conversation, but time is running out. And plus, anyone can come in here!
elaboration3_10.speaker: robot

elaboration3_11.dialogue: Yes, you're right, we need to free our father and go look for the computer already!
elaboration3_11.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_12.dialogue: But first, I'll read the theory...

elaboration3_13.dialogue: Lists are an important structure in Prolog. Lists allow you to store arbitrary amounts of data.

elaboration3_14.dialogue: A linked list is a data structure made up of nodes. Each node contains data and a reference to one or two adjacent nodes.

elaboration3_15.dialogue: Lists in Prolog are singly linked, meaning each node contains only one reference. There are built-in functions for working with lists:
elaboration3_15.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_16.dialogue: `sum_list(List, Sum)` — calculates the sum of the list elements
elaboration3_16.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_17.dialogue: `member(Elem, List)` — searches for a value in a list. Successful if the element is found.
elaboration3_17.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_19.dialogue: `length(List, Length)` — calculates the length of the list
elaboration3_19.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_20.dialogue: `append(List1, List2, List1AndList2)` — function of merging two lists
elaboration3_20.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_21.dialogue: `delete(InputList, Elem, ResultList)` — function of deleting all elements with a given value from the list.
elaboration3_21.speaker: vicky

elaboration3_22.dialogue: And I didn't even know that such functions existed... let's try to apply them now.
elaboration3_22.speaker: vicky

elaboration4_01.dialogue: Let me help you get out, professor?
elaboration4_01.speaker: robot

elaboration4_02.dialogue: I can still crawl out from under the table myself. Thank you! Quiet! Do you hear those sounds?
elaboration4_02.speaker: professor

elaboration4_05.dialogue: It sounds like some kind of mooing . The sounds are coming from that far corner of the room...
elaboration4_05.speaker: professor

elaboration4_06.dialogue: Let's go see who's there! Need to shine a flashlight...
elaboration4_06.speaker: vicky

elaboration4_06_1.dialogue: Yes, this is the kidnapped information specialist safety Sarah Parker! I'll help you now!

elaboration4_07.dialogue: Are you Professor Langdon?! My name is Sarah Parker! Kevin Mitnick kidnapped me from my own home last night! He's gone crazy and he must be stopped immediately!
elaboration4_07.speaker: sarah

elaboration4_08.dialogue: I thought the director would turn to you for help!
elaboration4_08.speaker: sarah

elaboration4_09.dialogue: It's a pleasure to meet you, miss, I honestly didn't expect to see you here!
elaboration4_09.speaker: professor

elaboration4_10.dialogue: Please help me get free! I know where the main computer is! We need to hurry, there's not much time left!
elaboration4_10.speaker: sarah

elaboration4_11.dialogue: Allow me to introduce you to my daughter Vicky. We will now complete the task together and enter the correct code to free you, miss.
elaboration4_11.speaker: professor

elaboration4_12.dialogue: I have heard about you, miss, as much as about your outstanding father. I believe that you will succeed!
elaboration4_12.speaker: sarah

elaboration4_13.dialogue: Then let's get started! Let's read the theory...
elaboration4_13.speaker: professor

elaboration4_14.dialogue: Let's consider an example when facts are connected by a conditional relationship with other already known facts, in this case they can be called rules:
elaboration4_14.speaker: professor

elaboration4_15.dialogue:
`likes(professor, X) :- likes(vicky, X).`
`% The professor likes everything that Vicky likes`
elaboration4_15.speaker: professor

elaboration4_16.dialogue:
`likes(professor, X)` is the rule's header.
`likes(vicky, X)` is the rule's body or tail target.
elaboration4_16.speaker: professor

elaboration4_17.dialogue: For a rule to be true, its tail targets must be true.
elaboration4_17.speaker: professor

elaboration4_18.dialogue: The `:-` symbol serves to separate the two parts of a rule: the header and the body. You can use `if` instead.
elaboration4_18.speaker: professor

elaboration4_19.dialogue: I understand everything, let's move on to the task...
elaboration4_19.speaker: vicky

elaboration4_21.dialogue: Okay... Looks like the trap is deactivated.

elaboration6_start.speaker: sarah
elaboration6_start.dialogue: Thank you for helping to free me! Now we can't delay, time is short, let's move on!

elaboration6_01.dialogue: Agreed, let's go. Look! What a machine!
elaboration6_01.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_02.dialogue: It's not a supercomputer, of course, but it's still quite powerful...
elaboration6_02.speaker: professor

elaboration6_03.dialogue: Look, the computer is on and downloading some files. Let's see what's there?
elaboration6_03.speaker: sarah

elaboration6_04.dialogue: Here's a whole list of encrypted personal data of US Mint employees. As far as I know, only 10 of them have access to the Fort Knox vault.
elaboration6_04.speaker: professor

elaboration6_05.dialogue: To get inside the vault, each of them must enter their part of the code, and then 'sim-sim' will open its doors.
elaboration6_05.speaker: professor

elaboration6_06.dialogue: In the entire history of Fort Knox, only three times have outsiders gotten into it.
elaboration6_06.speaker: professor

elaboration6_07.dialogue: Who was given such an honor and why were they able to get there?
elaboration6_07.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_08.dialogue: The first of those who got there was American President Roosevelt in 1943. And the second time the reserves were checked only 31 years later.
elaboration6_08.speaker: professor

elaboration6_09.dialogue: And the third inspection happened in 2018, as rumors began to circulate that there was no gold in the vault. But this turned out to be just rumors, all the gold was in place.
elaboration6_09.speaker: professor

elaboration6_10.dialogue: I wonder if the mint employees are also in on Mitnik or if he wants to use them in secret?
elaboration6_10.speaker: sarah

elaboration6_11.dialogue: We'll definitely figure this out later, but now we need to stop the virus and enter the code before anyone interferes with us.
elaboration6_11.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_12.dialogue: Yes, let's get started. I'm ready now.
elaboration6_12.speaker: robot

elaboration6_13.dialogue: When Prologue encounters a rule rather than a fact during goal resolution, it first unifies the rule's heading
elaboration6_13.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_14.dialogue: i.e. compares bound variables and assigns values ​​to free variables.
elaboration6_14.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_15.dialogue: If the arguments are successfully unified, the argument values ​​from the header are substituted into the first predicate in the rule body.
elaboration6_15.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_16.dialogue: and sets this predicate as a subgoal, which it begins to unify with the knowledge base.
elaboration6_16.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_17.dialogue: If unification of this condition predicate fails, then a rollback to the previous rule condition is performed.
elaboration6_17.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_18.dialogue: This rollback only occurs if this previous predicate is ambiguous. Let's explain this with an example.
elaboration6_18.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_19.dialogue: `parent (Who, Vicky)` -- The Who variable in the goal predicate is a free variable.
elaboration6_19.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_20.dialogue: We could have used `X` instead of `Who`, and they would have been different variables that would unify in the same way.
elaboration6_20.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_21.dialogue: Interesting, interesting... let's move on to the task.
elaboration6_21.speaker: vicky

elaboration6_failTask6_01.dialogue: Try again. You made a mistake in your answer.

elaboration6_23.dialogue: I can't believe it... but your solution works!

0B_1.dialogue: All hope is on dad. If only he could stop the virus from downloading...

1B_start.speaker: anonymous
1B_start.dialogue: File `antivirus.pl` successfully downloaded and deployed to server...

1B_2.dialogue: Now it would be good to stop the virus itself from loading and destroy it... All hope is on dad, he should cope!

2B_start.speaker: anonymous
2B_start.dialogue: ...2 ...1 ...0. The virus has been successfully downloaded and launched on the server...

2A_1.speaker: vicky
2A_1.dialogue: No!.. Is there really nothing we can do?

2A_2.speaker: professor
2A_2.dialogue: I'm afraid so... In the next few minutes, the virus will wreak havoc across the entire World Wide Web.

2A_3.speaker: vicky
2A_3.dialogue: That's what happened. Just an hour later, reports of disasters began to come in -- in space, in the air, in data centers.

2A_4.dialogue: If only we could start over...

3B_start.speaker: anonymous
3B_start.dialogue: Sorry, the file `antivirus.pl` could not be loaded.

3A_1.speaker: vicky
3A_1.dialogue: Why is that? It's just impossible...

3A_2.speaker: professor
3A_2.dialogue: Luckily, I was able to at least interrupt the virus download and destroy it.

3A_4.speaker: mitnik
3A_4.dialogue: I wrote the virus on a flash drive that I always carry with me especially for this case.

3A_5.dialogue: As long as I have the source code of the virus in my hands, I can rule the world!

4B_start.speaker: anonymous
4B_start.dialogue: 2... 1... 0... The file `antivirus.pl` was successfully downloaded and deployed on the server.

4A_1.speaker: vicky
4A_1.dialogue: Hurray! Now the global network is protected from the virus.

4A_2.speaker: professor
4A_2.dialogue: ...Unfortunately, I was late, and the virus was downloaded.

4A_4.speaker: mitnik
4A_4.dialogue: In the first hours, your defenses will not yet learn to recognize it. And the virus will also evolve.

4A_5.dialogue: And while he is free... I will be able to rule the world!

5B_start.speaker: anonymous
5B_start.dialogue: ...3 ...2 ...1... Are you sure you want to run the `antivirus.pl` file?

5A_5.speaker: director
5A_5.dialogue: Professor... we just received a message about the launch of your antivirus!

5A_6.dialogue: With its help, a copy of the Mitnick virus was caught, neutralized and sent to the lab for safe testing.

5A_7.speaker: professor
5A_7.dialogue: Well, I hope the latest heuristic algorithms will quickly learn to recognize such threats.

5A_9.speaker: director
5A_9.dialogue: He was caught and arrested by our best operative, Agent Steve.

5A_10.dialogue: This hacker is no longer a threat to society.

5A_11.speaker: vicky
5A_11.dialogue: As the director said, Mitnick was arrested. Soon the police got to his accomplices.

5A_12.dialogue: Father said that he would start working on a treatise on logical programming...

5A_13.dialogue: I was later offered to become a white hat hacker and help different companies... I don't know if I'll agree.

limbo_2.dialogue: Somehow you blacked out during your adventure.

limbo_3.dialogue: Alas, although it is not your fault...

limbo_4.dialogue: My virus has already been launched into the network and is currently penetrating billions of devices.

limbo_5.dialogue: And in a matter of hours, chaos will swallow the entire Internet, all electronics!

task0.questionText: What does the `:-` sign mean in Prolog?

task1.questionText: What does `X \= Y` mean in a rule?

task2.questionText:
The following facts are given:```character(professor).
character(vicky).
character(mitnik).```What will the query `character(_).` return?

task3.questionText: How to split the list `[1, 2, 3, 4]` into two lists: `[1, 2]` and `[3, 4]`?

task4.questionText:
The knowledge base contains the following facts and rule:```investigation(fbi, evidence).
character(mitnik).
involved_in_investigation(X, Y) :-
	investigation(Y, evidence), character(X).```What will be output as a result of the query `involved_in_investigation(X, fbi).`?

task6.questionText:
Write a query to check if Vicky is related to the virus.```character(vicky).
character(mitnik).
develop(mitnik, virus).
involved(X) :- develop(X, virus).```The answer does not need to be written to a variable.
